journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology

title-group.article-title: An experimentally validated numerical model of indentation and abrasion by debris particles in machine-element contacts considering micro-hardness effects

article-meta.aff: Mechanical Engineering Department, Imperial College London, UK

author-notes.corresp: George K Nikas, Tribology Group, Mechanical Engineering Department, Imperial College London, Exhibition Road, London SW7 2AZ, UK. Email: gnikas@teemail.gr

abstract.p: Indentation and abrasion of machine-element contacts by solid contamination particles is a major problem in many industries and manufacturing processes involving the automotive, aerospace, medical and electronics industries among others. Published theoretical studies on indentation and soft abrasion of surfaces by ductile debris particles other than those of the author are based on several major simplifications concerning material properties, hardness, plasticity modelling, interfacial friction, kinematic conditions, etc. None of the studies published in the literature to date (2011) have those simplifications concurrently relaxed.

In view of the shortcomings of existing numerical models on debris particle indentation and abrasion, and given the importance of dent geometry and size on fatigue life of machine elements, a greatly improved numerical model has been developed based on the previous studies of the author. The new model deals with elastoplastic indentation and abrasion of rolling–sliding, dry and lubricated contacts by spherical particles of any hardness, from very soft (e.g. 40 HV) to very hard (e.g. over 1000 HV), including harder than the contact counterfaces. The model incorporates strain-hardening and strain-gradient or indentation-size micro-hardness effects with an expanding-cavity plasticity model, a localised treatment of friction, generalised boundary and kinematic conditions involving localised stick and slip of the particle, linear and nonlinear work-hardening models of the particle, a basic approach on pile-up/sink-in plasticity effects and several other improvements. The model has passed extensive validation tests and found to give realistic predictions that are quantitatively quite close to the experimental results published by independent researchers in the literature concerning dent dimensions and slope. Moreover, it has verified and explained theoretically for the first time the formation of dimples inside and outside dents experimentally observed in rolling and rolling–sliding contacts. This article presents the mathematics of the model, the validation procedure with several real cases from the experimental literature, and a parametric study to show the model’s predictions on precise dent geometry in several realistic cases.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Particulate contamination is a persistent problem affecting many industrial sectors, particularly in industries with high cleanliness requirements such as the medical and pharmaceutical, aerospace, food and electronics industry. Machine elements such as bearings, gears, axles, engine pistons, valves, dynamic seals and others are normally operating in the presence of thousands to millions of particulates in their intimate environment, which range in size from nanometres to micrometres.1,2 Debris particles vary in shape and morphology from spheres (e.g. products of metal fatigue), smooth ovoids (dust) and fibres (polymers, cotton, wool) to curls and spirals (machining debris), rolls, platelets and flakes (paint, products of running-in metal wear, etc.), and irregularly shaped objects such as chunks and slabs (rock debris, products of metal fatigue, etc.)—see Table 1 in the studies of Nikas1,2 or refer to the original sources.3,4 Debris originate from many sources including (a) internal sources, e.g. new oils (see the studies of Kjer,5 Jones,6 Leng and Davies,7 and Stachowiak et al.8 and Figure 2 in the studies of Nikas1,2); (b) wear processes9–12 including abrasion, adhesion, erosion, contact fatigue, spalling and scuffing; (c) external, environmental sources such as air and water carrying sand, dust, swarf, grits from machining operations, glass fragments, etc., which usually contaminate mechanical systems due to insufficient sealing or are introduced during repair and maintenance such as lubricant changes, replacement of filters and seals, etc. Table 1.

Many experimental studies from as early as the 1920 s13 have shown the detrimental effects of debris particles in machine-element operation, particularly in bearings. Such effects include increase of friction and temperature,13–16 dramatic increase of wear17–23 even by soft particles, increase of vibration and noise,24–27 and a substantial—often orders of magnitude—decrease of component fatigue life.28–46 The scale of the risks involved in machine failure from solid contaminants is realised by the following statements and findings:
‘The presence of dirt or grit in ball bearings is responsible for over 90% of all bearing failures; where bearings are kept clean during mounting, are lubricated with clean oil and are protected by recommended closures, no difficulty should be experienced from this source.’47
‘Several 6305 deep groove ball bearings with and without seals were tested in a highly contaminated environment (a gearbox with a considerable number of wear particles). No failures of the sealed bearings occurred and the tests were discontinued for practical reasons after the sealed bearings had run for periods which were at least 30 times longer than the experimental lives of the unsealed bearings. The unsealed bearing lives equalled 0.1 of the calculated L10 life … ’48
Approximately 20% of all bearing rejections in aircraft engine, transmission and accessory bearings was attributed to debris particles in a 1979 study concerning aircraft propulsion systems49—see also a similar study from the same year.50
Solid contamination was the cause of failure in an estimated 75% of all bearings that failed before reaching their rated lives according to a 2001 publication by Ai51 on behalf of The Timken Company in USA.
Needelman and Zaretsky35 in 1991 presented two equations to adjust the rolling-bearing L10 (or catalogue) life based upon oil filter rating and recommended that ‘…where no oil filtration is used, catalogue life be reduced by 50%.’ Several other, similarly bold cases exist in the literature—see for example section 4 in the study of Nikas1 for a review.

There are three main mechanisms of debris induced damage to concentrated machine-element contacts.
The indirect mechanism. This concerns particles physico-chemically degrading liquid lubricants. It refers to change of the effective lubricant viscosity, followed by changes in frictional performance,52–54 accelerated oil oxidation, corrosion, interference with and neutralisation of lubricant additives such as zinc-dialkyl-dithiophosphate, etc.28,55–58
The secondary direct mechanism. This concerns particles blocking the inlet zone of lubricated contacts and causing lubricant starvation, film collapse and, eventually, catastrophic wear such as scuffing55,59–65 (see also the reviews in section 6 in the study of Nikas1 or section 5.5 in the study of Nikas2).
The primary direct mechanism. This concerns particles entering concentrated contacts and causing surface plastic deformation as in indentation66–68 and abrasion.69–79 This is the most common mechanism of particle-induced damage to concentrated contacts and will be analysed in this article.

The mechanism of surface plastic indentation from debris particles has been studied both experimentally40,41,66–68,80–88 and theoretically via elementary stress analysis66,67,83 and via finite-element analysis (FEA).80,83,89–91 Similarly, the literature on abrasive wear is voluminous and some of the most important studies in relation to debris induced damage can be found in the studies of Broeder and Heijnekamp,16 Ronen and Malkin,19,20 Dwyer-Joyce and coworkers,69–80 Hutchings,92 Williams and Hyncica,93 and Fang et al.94 The literature and theoretical modelling in particular on particle indentation and abrasion is discussed in detail later in this article. A literature review1,2 reveals that existing numerical models of particle induced indentation and abrasion are severely restricted by simplifying assumptions to tackle or rather avoid the complex mathematics of the theory of plasticity. For example, in purely rolling contacts, ductile particles have been modelled by Hamer et al.66,67 as perfectly plastic discs compressed axisymmetrically at low speed between purely elastic, flat counterfaces; the curved geometry of the counterfaces is ignored as is the fluid pressure on the particles in elastohydrodynamic contacts, the heating between the particles and the counterfaces owed to friction, micro-hardness effects involving strain-hardening and strain-gradient plasticity, and more. Hamer et al.’s66,67,83 model was eventually extended to cover plastic deformations in rolling contacts via Johnson’s cavity model (see section 6.3 in the study of Johnson95) as well as via FEA, again with several simplifying assumptions and major restrictions such as the lack of sliding of the contact counterfaces. Similar simplifications were used in modelling abrasive wear. For example, abrasive particles are typically treated as rigid solids that dig in one of the contact surfaces and plough grooves of material out of the counter-surface.80 Such models66,67,80,83 have satisfactorily correlated—within their region of validity—with experimental results and have led to some useful equations to predict the onset of damage. For example, equation (1) in the study of Nikas,1 which originates from Hamer and co-workers,66,67,87 estimates the critical particle size or hardness resulting in indentation of plastic surfaces as function of the hardness of the counterfaces and the friction coefficient between the particle and the counterfaces in a rolling contact. Similar equations such as equations (2) and (3) in the study of Nikas1 have been provided by Ai.51 Such simple equations are useful as a first approximation but should not be relied upon when precision is important (see a comparison in Figure 2.13 in the study of Underwood82) or when the contact conditions significantly deviate from those assumed in the derivation of said simple formulae.

Some of the modelling restrictions were relaxed when FEA was employed to study ductile-particle indentation. The elastoplastic FEA of Ko and Ioannides89 in 1989 dealt with the axisymmetric contact of a spherical particle on a flat surface but used the particle pressure from the model of Hamer et al.,67 as prescribed loading for the FEA. This was followed by similar fundamental analyses by Hamer and Hutchinson83 and Dwyer-Joyce.80 Generally, their theoretical calculations were in good agreement with experimental results although in several cases, dent geometry and size were not close to those measured, particularly for high and low ratios of particle diameter over lubricated-contact film thickness (see for example the studies of Hamer et al.,67,83 as well as the dent-size comparisons in Table 3.6 of the study of Dwyer-Joyce80). More recent FEA results have been published by Xu et al.,96 who used a rigid spherical indenter, Kang et al.,90 who modelled a spherical particle in elastoplastic compression between circular cylinders in a rolling, dry contact, and Antaluca and Nélias,91 who modelled a spherical particle in elastoplastic, axisymmetric compression in a rolling, dry contact.

From the aforementioned studies, it is clear that many major simplifications have been used, namely: assumed material rigidity; absence of contact sliding (uniaxial compression or rolling contact at best); absence of lubrication effects (dry contact); absence of thermal effects (no particle frictional heating as demonstrated by this author in the study of Nikas et al.59,62,97–99); absence of particle work hardening during its plastic deformation; absence of strain-hardening effects of plastically deforming contact surfaces in most of the studies; absence of strain-gradient or indentation-size effects, which are inherent in micro-indentation (indentation at micrometre scale);100–104 elementary treatment of friction between a particle and the contact counterfaces via Amontons’ second law without localised variations owed to, for example, plastic shear; lack of finite-element model re-meshing to compensate for particle flattening in FEA, which generates questions on the validity of some results, particularly for high ratios of particle size over contact gap or film thickness. None of the studies published in the literature to date (2011) have concurrently relaxed all of the previously listed simplifications.

In previous modelling work by the author, several important elements were incorporated to add realism and precision to the debris deformation analysis. Among said elements are fluid forces on particles passing through elastohydrodynamic contacts, frictional heating due to rapid particle deformation and shearing when squashed to pass through narrow contact gaps, and kinematic conditions involving both rolling and sliding of the cooperating surfaces.59,62,97–99 The result was a complex model of elastoplastic particle squashing in elastohydrodynamic rolling–sliding contacts with fluid and transient thermoelastic effects, capable of predicting the onset of subsurface yield with a three-dimensional (3D) thermoelastic stress analysis. However, the author’s previous model lacked the ability to calculate plastic displacements of the contact surfaces, which means that surface dents or scars and grooves could not be computed.

The value in precisely computing the size and shape of dents and scars of debris-damaged surfaces stems from the known correlation between said surface features and the fatigue life of the damaged component. This has been shown in several experimental studies23,31–46,51 and theoretical studies.86,89,91,96,105–111 For example, Ai and Nixon110 found that the fatigue life is strongly influenced by the indentation area density and dent slope, particularly for slopes over 5°. The effect of a dent’s slope on fatigue life of the dented surface has also been shown by Lubrecht et al.,111 who found that the reduction of life is proportional to the depth of the dent and inversely proportional to its wavelength in line contacts. Obviously, even the fact that a model is capable of predicting the generation of a dent or not is in itself valuable in risk assessment and wear evaluation. If the model could, additionally, be capable of precise computation of dent shape and dimensions, that would be ideal.

In view of the shortcomings of existing numerical models on debris particle indentation and abrasion, and given the importance of dent geometry and size on fatigue life of machine elements, a greatly improved numerical model has been developed by the author based on his previous model.99 The new model deals with elastoplastic indentation and abrasion of rolling–sliding, dry or lubricated contacts by spherical particles of any hardness, from very soft—such as lead and aluminium—to very hard (hardness in excess of 1000 Vickers), including harder than the contact counterfaces. The model incorporates strain-hardening and strain-gradient or indentation-size micro-hardness effects with an expanding-cavity plasticity model,112 a localised treatment of friction, generalised boundary and kinematic conditions including stick and slip at the particle contact interface, linear and nonlinear work-hardening models of the particle, a basic approach on pile-up/sink-in plasticity effects and several other improvements detailed in later sections of the paper. Most importantly, the model has passed extensive validation tests and found to give realistic predictions that are quite close quantitatively to the experimental results published by independent researchers in the literature, including dent dimensions and slope, as is presented later in the paper. In fact, it was developed and optimised with close reference to experimental studies on soft- and hard-particle indentation and abrasion. Moreover, it has verified and explained theoretically the formation of dimples and dent features experimentally observed by Ville and Nelias46,68,81 in rolling and rolling–sliding contacts.

The model is not capable of calculating the precise geometry of dent shoulders in cases of material pile-up but can offer an estimation. In fact, pile-up has not been modelled in any particle damage-related published studies and is a complex topic even with FEA with simple, axisymmetric compression; moreover, the author doubts that this could ever be resolved for sliding contacts without resorting to FEA. Finally, for reasons of clarity and priority, thermal effects from particle frictional heating are not incorporated in this article, but will be presented in a follow-up study.

sec.title: Introductory remarks
sec.p: The core of this numerical model was developed in the studies of Nikas et al.59,62,97–99,113 for ductile particles. The last version of the model99 had the following three parts.

The first part is the modelling of particle entrapment in line and point elastohydrodynamic contacts,59,113 eventually extended to elliptical contacts.114,115 This is used to establish if a spherical particle will be trapped in a concentrated contact and accounts for mechanical and fluid forces on the particle, the latter in case of lubricated conditions (Figure 1). Obviously, the analysis of particle elastoplastic deformation is not performed unless the entrapment criteria are satisfied.113–115 Figure 1.
Spherical particle in elastic contact with the surfaces of an elliptical, lubricated contact at the initial stage of entrapment. Figure 2.
Process of particle compression and extrusion between contact surfaces 1 and 2. The undisturbed surfaces have nominal tangential velocities u1 and u2, and a relative normal velocity dh(xp,yp)/dt.

The second part is about modelling how a ductile particle passes through a concentrated contact.59,62,99 This involves resolution of mechanical contact forces on the particle and fluid forces in the presence of a lubricant, the outcome being the evaluation of particle’s motion. It also involves calculations of the elastic displacements of the contact surfaces in the presence of the particle. The latter includes thermoelastic strains,59,62,97–99 as were summarised in the study of Nikas.99 Thermal modelling is necessitated by the friction between the particle and the contact counter-surfaces as well as particle’s internal friction during its usually very rapid plastic deformation.
The third part involves a 3D, subsurface, thermoelastic stress analysis and checking if plastic deformation is expected based on the Mises yield criterion.59,98,99

The model in the study of Nikas99 is here expanded to cover elastoplastic deformations of the contact surfaces. Due to the extent of new features and for the purposes of experimental validation and order of presentation, the thermal part of the model, that is, frictional heating, flash temperatures and thermal strains, is omitted; it is fundamentally similar to that in the study of Nikas99 and will be included in a follow-up publication with detailed results and additional, flash-temperature experimental evidence.

sec.title: Particle partitioning into blocks and collapse under pressure
sec.p: The analysis begins by checking the particle entrapment criteria for line and circular contacts113 or generally elliptical contacts,114 depending on application. If the criteria are satisfied, the particle will be trapped and will pass through the contact. In such a case, the particle will immediately attain an ellipsoidal shape as it is compressed between the contact surfaces and will eventually be deformed to a thin platelet—see for example the experimental work of Wan and Spikes.63 For typically small debris particles (e.g. particle diameter D < 100 µm) and typical machine-element contacts as in roller bearings, the slope of the undeformed contact surfaces can be ignored as was explained in previous publications of the author.62,97,99 Said slope of a few degrees is actually of the same order of magnitude as the gradient of the elastic or plastic displacements of the contact surfaces under the deforming particle. In fact, the latter will exceed the slope of the undeformed contact surfaces near or inside the (almost flat) Hertzian zone of the contact. It is therefore justifiable to use a model of the deforming particle as the one depicted in Figure 2, namely a barrel-shaped solid trapped between two surfaces, which have a normal velocity of approach and tangential velocities. The normal velocity of particle compression is dh(xp,yp)/dt, that is, the temporal derivative of the undisturbed contact gap thickness at coordinates (xp, yp), which are the first two coordinates of particle’s centre K(xp, yp, zp). Moreover, assuming a typical contact with 1D rolling and/or sliding—say on the x-axis—as for example in roller bearings, the undeformed contact surfaces in Figure 2 have tangential velocities u1 and u2.

The deforming particle is next partitioned into blocks. Figure 3 shows the partitioning with very few blocks for visualisation purposes. Typically, there are 1300–5000 blocks for any particle, regardless of particle size. Each block has dimensions Δs × Δs × H, where H is the height of a block, which is the sum of the height (h) of the local contact gap and the local, surfacial, normal elastoplastic displacements w1 and w2 (1) where (xb, yb) are the coordinates of the block. The height h of the local contact gap, which is the same as the local film thickness in case of lubricated contacts, refers to the undisturbed contact, that is, the contact in the absence of the particle. The calculation of h is based on the theory of Hertz for a dry contact95 and the elastohydrodynamic theory for a lubricated contact.116 In case of elastohydrodynamics, a thermal correction factor of the film thickness is taken into account (see section 20.8 in the study of Hamrock et al.116). The calculation of displacements w1 and w2 in equation (1) is detailed later. Figure 3.
Particle (depicted as a circle) partitioned into blocks of dimensions Δs × Δs × H, and stresses in one typical block named A. In this example, block A is subject to normal stresses σx, σy (not visible in the figure) and p (solid pressure), as well as fluid pressure pf (pf = 0 in case of a dry contact). Block A is also subject to resultant shear stresses τ1 (shown) and τ2 (on face 2, not visible in the figure) from friction with the contact counter-surfaces.

The basic dimension of the square counterfaces of a block is (2) where R is the radius of the deforming particle disc as shown in Figure 2, which changes in time as the particle deforms, and Ny the set number of blocks along radius R on the y-axis (x = 0). After the initial stage of entrapment where the particle is elastically compressed, the particle enters a plastic state in which, according to classic plasticity theory, it is incompressible (Poisson’s ratio equals 0.5). This means that its volume during fully plastic deformation is conserved while its shape is changing. Thus, applying volume conservation and as long as the load supported by the particle (F) is less than the contact load (L), radius R is approximated as follows (3) where i = [xb/Δs], j = [yb/Δs] (square brackets denote the integer part of the enclosed argument in this case) are the discrete coordinates of a block and V the volume of the particle at a given time. Initially, V = πD3/6. However, if the particle sticks to both contact surfaces with the contact pressure exceeding the shear strength of the particle, material of the particle will adhere to the contact surfaces and volume V will be accordingly reduced, as is calculated later. Moreover, it is noted that the particle radius at any given time t cannot be lower than that at a past time if there is no sliding in the contact. Furthermore, the radius will obviously remain unchanged if the load supported by the particle equals the contact load. The last two constraints are expressed as follows (4) where Δt is the time step used in the numerical analysis. For simplicity of presentation, the reported equation (3) is applicable to line contacts with b standing for the Hertzian zone semi-width. A similar analysis is applicable to a more general elliptical contact. Finally, it is obvious that equation (3) is nonlinear in R, which necessitates a numerical solution.

As the particle is severely deformed to become a thin disc or ellipsoid, internal shear stresses at the boundaries of neighbouring blocks are much weaker than the normal stresses σx and σy of a block. This argument is further supported by the negligible height difference of neighbouring blocks (normally in the order of nanometres or less), solely attributable to the variation of surface deflections under the particle. The force equilibrium of a block on the x and y axes then yields (5) where τ1,k and τ2,k (k = x, y) are the x and y components of the resultant shear stresses τ1 and τ2 on the upper and lower faces of a block (Figure 3).

sec.title: Local kinematics, particle tractions and stick–slip issues
sec.p: In order to calculate the shear stresses from friction at the interfaces between the particle and the contact surfaces (zones P1P2P3 and P4P5P6 in Figure 2), local kinematics and stick–slip issues need to be resolved as they dictate the direction and magnitude of the shear stress vectors. From simple kinematics and the geometry of the problem, the x and y components of the velocities of a block with discrete coordinates (i, j) at the interfaces with surfaces 1 and 2 are given by (6) where Vp1 and Vp2 are the velocities of the particle’s centre in relation to surfaces 1 and 2, respectively, and (7) is the extrusion velocity of the particle, that is, the velocity of lateral extension during its compression. Analytically, equation (7) signifies that the extrusion velocity equals zero if the particle’s centre lies inside the (nearly flat) Hertzian zone of the contact (xp > −b) or when the load supported by the particle (F) equals the contact load (L). In any other case, the extrusion velocity is computed by numerical differentiation of radius R with the help of equation (3), and is bounded by zero (negative extrusion velocity is impossible) and the maximum extrusion velocity, {V/[πh(xp,yp)]}1/2, which is attainable in the limiting case of rigid contact surfaces.

Shear stresses at zones P1P2P3 and P4P5P6 in Figure 2 can now be defined. In doing so, it is emphasised that those stresses cannot exceed the shear strength of the materials of the particle and the contact surfaces. Thus, two cases are distinguished.

Case 1: {R·≠0 or F = L or the deformations of the contact surfaces 1 and 2 are purely elastic}. In this case, the shear stress components for a block with discrete coordinates (i, j) are calculated as follows (8) (9) (10) (11) where (12)

In equations (8) to (11), sgn(x) is the sign function of argument x and equals 1 for x > 0 or −1 for x < 0; moreover, μ1 and μ2 are the kinetic friction coefficients between the particle and surfaces 1 and 2, respectively, and G1, G2 and Gp stand for shear modulus of surface 1, 2 and the particle, respectively. The min{•} functions in equations (8) to (11) represent the constraint that shear stress cannot exceed the shear strength of the materials involved; thus, local stick and slip behaviour is taken care of by comparing μ1p and μ2p with G1, G2 and Gp. The sine and cosine terms in equations (8) to (11) refer to the direction of the resultant shear stress vectors τ1 and τ2 in regards to the x and y axes, which are dictated by the local kinematics.

Case 2: This case concerns the remaining possibility, namely {R·=0 and F ≠ L and there are plastic deformations on the contact surfaces 1 and 2}. The shear stress components are calculated as follows (13) (14) (15)

It is again noted that stick–slip issues at zones P1P2P3 and P4P5P6 in Figure 2 are effectively covered in equations (13) to (15) by both the local kinematics (velocities V1,x, V2,x and Vy = 0) and the condition that the shear strength of the materials is not exceeded (via the min{•} functions).

sec.title: Calculation of contact pressure on the particle
sec.p: As is obvious from equations (8) to (15), the contact pressure p on a block must be calculated in order to proceed with the analysis. Excluding the very first stage of particle entrapment where deformations are elastic, the remaining stage of particle deformation, which is by far the most extensive, involves elastoplastic or purely plastic deformations. The thickness of a typical deformed particle disc in a concentrated contact is very close to the contact gap or film thickness, namely a few nanometres up to a few micrometres. Hence, it is appropriate to apply the von Mises yield criterion for the normal and surfacial shear stresses applicable to a block, namely stresses σx, σy, p, τ1 and τ2. As was done earlier for the shear stresses, the same two cases are again distinguished.

Case 1: {R·≠0 or F = L or the deformations of contact surfaces 1 and 2 are purely elastic}. The von Mises criterion is then expressed as follows (16) where for simplicity, the (i, j) coordinates have been implied. In equation (16), pressure p is taken as negative by definition because it is compressive. The resultant shear stresses are (17) similar to the analysis in equations (8) and (9). Also in equation (16), the terms in square brackets multiplied by 3/2 result from accounting for the average shear stress, (|τ1| + |τ2|)/2 as the representative shear stress at the core of a block. Finally, Yp is the yield stress of the particle, which is a function of the particle hardness Hp. This is done in order to account for work hardening of the particle, as is explained later.

Case 2: {R·=0 and F ≠ L and there are plastic deformations on contact surfaces 1 and 2}. The von Mises criterion in this case is expressed as follows (18) where μk,eff (k = 1, 2) are the effective friction coefficients, similarly to equations (13) and (14) (19)

This treatment is again necessary in order to allow for stick–slip constraints to be satisfied in accordance with the shear strength of the materials involved. It is emphasised that in this case where velocity Vy = 0, the only local velocity component dictating stick or slip is Vk,x (k = 1, 2). For example, block (i, j) sticks to surface 1 when V1,x(i, j) = 0 and slips on surface 1 when V1,x(i, j) ≠ 0. Similar arguments hold for surface 2 per equation (19). If a block sticks to both surfaces in a sliding contact, either the block will shear internally for the contact surfaces to keep sliding in relation to each other or material from the contact surfaces will adhere to the block. This is the most complex situation, yet it is still resolved via equation (18), which symmetrically accounts for the shear strength of all materials involved—see the terms contained in the min{•} functions. Naturally, in case of gross plastic deformation of the contact surfaces during sliding with severe pile-up effects, nothing but FEA will suffice. Nevertheless, the present model has been applied to cases of abrasion and found to provide experimentally verifiable results, as is explained in the section about experimental validation later in the paper.

Returning to the issue of contact pressure calculation via the von Mises criterion, equations (16) to (18) are numerically solved for pressure p with the help of equation (5) for stresses σx and σy, and equations (6) to (17) for shear stresses and other required variables. The resolution requires an iterative process, whereby peripheral blocks such as block A in Figure 3 are treated first due to known boundary conditions (known fluid pressure for example), followed by neighbouring inner blocks and proceeding in a spiral manner to the centre of the particle. In any case, the pressure on any block is limited by the hardness of the contact surfaces and the particle (20) where h1 and h2 stand for micro-hardness of surfaces 1 and 2, respectively, and particle’s hardness Hp is calculated for an average particle thickness at the particular time of deformation equal to h(xp, yp) in order to account for work-hardening effects explained in section ‘Work hardening of the particle’. Moreover, if the stress problem is symmetric about the xz plane as in line contacts, symmetry is taken advantage of by solving the equations only in the y > 0 region and then setting p(i, −j) = p(i, j), τk,x(i, −j) = τk,x(i, j), τk,y(i, −j) = −τk,y(i, j) (k = 1, 2). It is important to note, as is detailed later, that if the calculated pressure exceeds the limiting value set by inequality (20), the excess pressure is relieved in the form of plastic displacements of at least one surface.

sec.title: Micro-hardness
sec.p: It is now timely to discuss the issue of micro-hardness, which is required in view of using h1 and h2 in inequality (20). Given the small size of typical debris particles, which is usually in the order of micrometres, the stress response of surfaces indented by such small indenters differs from that found in a typical macro-indentation with one of the classic methods (Rockwell, Brinell, Vickers, etc.). At small indentation scales involving micro-and nano-indentation of metals, hardness depends strongly on indentation depth and overall indent size, as well as on the indenter shape. The issue of indentation hardness, which is more than a century old, is a persistent topic in engineering literature; the reader may refer to the extensive reviews of Cheng and Cheng117,118 for a detailed presentation.

Micro-scale effects in metallic indentations associated with debris particles in machine-element contacts have been incorporated in just one numerical model, originally published by Hamer et al.66 in 1987. Hamer et al.’s model, which was used in later studies by Hamer and co-workers,67,80,83 utilised Johnson’s hemispherical-cavity model (see section 6.3 in the study of Johnson95). Johnson’s model, originally published in 1970,119 as well as earlier models by March120 in 1964 and Hirst and Howse121 in 1969, were based on the suggestion of Bishop et al.122 in 1945 that the stress distribution under a cylindrical punch with blunt conical head might be approximated by that met in an expanding spherical or cylindrical hole. Thus, Hill’s solution (see chapter V in the study of Hill123) for the quasi-static expansion of an internally pressurised spherical shell of an elastic-perfectly-plastic material was used in the aforementioned studies.119–121

However, there are some problems and inadequacies with this approach. Johnson’s model119 is known to underestimate hardness values.124 Moreover, classic cavity models such as Johnson’s have been shown to break down for materials of strong strain-hardening characteristics;100,125 strain hardening has not been incorporated in the classic expanding-cavity models. Furthermore, indentation tests100–104 have shown that for indentations with penetration depth in the order of micrometres, hardness depends on indentation size.

For the aforementioned reasons, the author turned to an alternative expanding-cavity model that has none of the shortcomings explained. It was published by Gao112 and is based on the strain-gradient plasticity theory. Gao’s model has shown good agreement with experimental results and is straightforward to incorporate into the present model of debris-induced plasticity. According to the expanding-cavity model of Gao112 for spherical indentations, hardness is calculated from the following equation (adapted to the present problem and notation) (21) where Yk and Ek stand for yield stress and elastic modulus, respectively, in regards to surfaces 1 and 2, nk the strain-hardening exponent (positive integer or zero), ck the strain-gradient coefficient and rk the radius of the spherical indenter. For elastic-perfectly-plastic materials, nk = 0; in this case, Gao112 applied l’Hôpital’s rule to equation (21) and obtained (22)

For nk = ck = 0, the expanding-cavity model expressed by equations (21) or (22) is similar to the original model of Johnson.119 The strain-gradient coefficient ck (k = 1, 2) in equations (21) and (22) is determined by curve fitting experimental data in the form of hardness versus depth of penetration. The strain-hardening exponent nk (k = 1, 2), which usually varies between 0.1 and 0.5, is determined from the stress–strain curve of the material. Finally, in the present debris model, the (0.2% offset) yield strength Yk is calculated from macro-hardness data by the empirical equation of Cahoon et al.126 (23) where Hk (k = 1, 2) stands for Vickers macro-hardness of surface 1 or 2.

It is seen in equations (21) and (22) that hardness changes as the penetration unfolds because it depends on the radius of the deforming particle disc, R (Figure 2 and equation (3)), and on the radius of the spherical indenter, rk (k = 1, 2). The ‘radius of the spherical indenter’ rk is realised as an equivalent radius of the particular indenter, which changes in time as penetration progresses, regardless of whether the latter is elastic, elastoplastic, or plastic. An elementary geometrical analysis leads to the following result (24) where wk (k = 1, 2) is the displacement on surface 1 or 2 at the contact zones of the particle (zones P1P2P3 and P4P5P6 in Figure 2), which could be elastic, elastoplastic or purely plastic. This concludes the method to calculate the dynamic surface hardness as the particle is deformed and the penetration proceeds.

sec.title: Work hardening of the particle
sec.p: In addition to the micro-hardness of the contact surfaces being affected by the indentation size and indenter shape, the hardness of a plastically deforming particle changes during deformation, too. This is owed to work hardening and affects equations (16) and (18) via particle’s yield stress, and inequality (20) via particle’s hardness. It is realised that, for example, a 30 -µm spherical ductile particle, flattened to a disc of less than 1 µm thickness to pass through a typical, heavily loaded, elastohydrodynamic contact, undergoes severe plastic deformation. Significant work hardening of the deforming particle is inevitable in such cases. For example, in his extensive experimental work,80 Dwyer-Joyce reported typical work-hardening ratios in the order of 40–60% for a variety of particles, including very soft (lead-tin solder), soft (aluminium and copper) and ‘mildly’ hard (mild steel and low-carbon steel) particles deformed in a press; hardness tests were performed by Hamer and Hutchinson83 using a Vickers micro-hardness machine. This affects not only particle hardness, as is obvious, but its yield stress, too. Extensive experimental evidence in the literature on spherical plastic indentation, which constitutes text-book material, suggests that the mean contact pressure or hardness when full plasticity is reached has an upper limit of 3.0 times the yield stress (see for example section 6.3 in Johnson95 or section 4.2.1.3 in Bhushan;127 see also Tabor’s classic study128 dating back to 1948). The value of 3.0 agrees with the slip-line field theory of plasticity for rigid-perfectly-plastic materials. This may not be directly applicable to the problem of spherical particle flattening from a particle’s perspective but it is used here as an approximation (25)

In regards to work hardening in relation to particle hardness, two models have been developed in this study: a linear and a quadratic model. They are unified in the following equation (26) where a0, a1 and a2 are constants, which are calculated from the following conditions: (a) Hp=H p (0) for h(xp,yp)=D, that is, at the beginning of deformation, particle hardness equals the nominal hardness H p (0) of the material of the particle; (b) Hp=Hp (λ)=(λ/100+1)Hp (0) for h(xp,yp)=hc, that is, at maximum particle compression, particle hardness equals the final particle hardness Hp (λ)(where hc is the central film thickness of the contact in the absence of the particle and λ is the percentage of work hardening (0 ≤ λ ≤ 100); (c) in addition to the previous two conditions, for the quadratic model it is also assumed that [∂Hp/∂h]h=D=0, that is, at the beginning of deformation, particle hardness starts increasing smoothly. With the previous conditions, the constants in equation (26) turn out to be (27) for the linear model and (28) for the quadratic model.

sec.title: Elastic surface displacements
sec.p: The next step concerns the calculation of the normal, elastic surface displacements wk (e) (k = 1, 2) at the coordinates of a block (xb, yb) caused by contact pressure p and surface tractions τk,x and τk,y (k = 1, 2) between the particle and surfaces 1 and 2 (Figure 2). This is achieved by utilising the Boussinesq–Cerruti potential functions for a distributed normal and tangential loading of a half-space.129 The result is (29) where k = 1 or 2, depending on which surface the calculation takes place, and νk stands for Poisson’s ratio. Taking advantage of the fact that a block’s faces are flat and square, the tricky numerical integration in equation (29) can be substituted by a robust analytical computation. This is based on the exact calculation of the normal surface displacement under a block of uniform pressure as analysed by Love130 (see for example equation (3.25) in Johnson95), which was extended by the author to cover normal displacements from tangential tractions, too, as in the study of Nikas.131 Therefore, instead of using equation (29) to compute the elastic displacements, the following equation is applicable (30) where the terms in the summations for the present problem are (31) (32) (33) where x±≡(i±0.5)δ-xb and y±≡(j±0.5)δ-yb.

sec.title: Plastic and total surface displacements
sec.p: In order to proceed with the analysis, the surface displacements wk (k = 1, 2) are required in equation (24). First, it is logical to assume that if surface plasticity is detected and a block of the particle is to penetrate both the contact surfaces, the total penetration could be partitioned between the two contact surfaces as follows (34) where δ1 and δ2 stand for penetration to surfaces 1 and 2, respectively, and Δh is the reduction of the contact gap at the coordinates of the centre of the particle (xp, yp) during a time step at a given time t in the absence of the particle.

It is now time to formulate the indentation of one or both surfaces. The surfacial displacements, w1 and w2, under a block with coordinates (xb, yb) of the particle, are calculated as follows (35) (36) where w1 (r) and w2 (r) are the indents at (xb, yb) of surfaces 1 and 2, respectively, one time step before the time which equations (35) and (36) are applicable for. The logic behind equations (35) and (36) is on comparing the contact pressure of a block with the micro-hardness of each surface and, subsequently, partitioning the plastic displacements under the block between the two surfaces if micro-hardness is exceeded by the contact pressure according to equation (34). Naturally, if the contact pressure is lower than the micro-hardness of both surfaces, the only local surface displacement is that owed to elastic deflection at present time and residual dents from past time, as is clear from the first rows in equations (35) and (36).

sec.title: Particle sticking, particle motion and convergence checks
sec.p: With the stress and displacement analysis as previously detailed, it should be noted that micro-hardness is evaluated and updated using the average contact pressure of the particle. Another important issue concerns the sticking of the particle to both contact surfaces (which occurs when min{μ1, μ2}p > Gp) in the case of a sliding contact. In such a case, some of the particle’s material will adhere to the contact surfaces and the volume of the particle will be reduced. Assuming that the volume of adhered material equals the volume of displaced material of surfaces 1 and 2 at the contact zones of the particle, the reduced volume of the particle at the next time step t + Δt is duly expressed as follows (37) on the obvious condition that V(t + Δt) ≥ 0.

The steps described so far involve lower-level numerical loops to check convergence such as those associated with the computation of particle local contact pressure. If the local contact pressure is not within 5% of the previously computed value in a lower level iteration and this takes place to at least Ny blocks, then a higher level iteration involving the average contact pressure on the particle is performed. The latter involves under-relaxing the average contact pressure by a factor of 0.2 in accordance to hardness constraints and re-computing all variables until convergence of the average contact pressure is achieved. In addition to the aforementioned checks, the load supported by the particle, F, is checked against the total load of the contact, L, as already explained with regards to equation (7) (38)
If F = L, the implications are realised from equation (7) and subsequent equations affected by it.

Having completed all computations at a given time t, the particle is allowed to move in the contact during a time step Δt according to the distribution of tractions on its surfaces and the fluid forces exerted on it in case of a lubricated contact. Due to the large extent of this part of the analysis, which is published in the study of Nikas et al.97 by the author, it is omitted here. For the analysis of static and dynamic fluid forces on the particle, the reader is referred to the author’s publications for line contacts,97 for circular contacts,113 and for generally elliptical contacts.114 For the analysis of particle motion, which is based on Newton’s second law, the reader is referred to section 2.1 and equation (20) in the study of Nikas97 for line contacts.

sec.title: Indentation pile-up and sink-in effects
sec.p:
In indentation experiments to evaluate material hardness, pile-up characterises a concentration of displaced material of the indented solid at the edges of the contact between the indenter and the indented solid. Pile-up means that material is displaced above the original surface that is indented (Figure 4). If this does not happen, the plastically deforming surface upon removal of the indenter will be lower than the original surface in the area around the dent, a phenomenon referred to as sink-in. In terms of stress concentration, crack initiation, transient elastohydrodynamics and contact fatigue, pile-up is much more important and critical than sink-in. Pile-up leads to the development of shoulders around dents. Residual stress concentration at the shoulders of such dents can initiate cracks. The shoulders are also associated with high pressure spikes in both dry and elastohydrodynamically lubricated contacts when the dents are overrolled. This has been studied both theoretically and experimentally in many literature studies as for example in the studies of Ville and Nelias,44 Sayles and Ioannides,86 Xu et al.,96,106 and Coulon et al.132,133 Figure 4.
Pile-up (s1 > s0) and sink-in (s1 < s0).

Unfortunately, modelling pile-up geometry without resorting to FEA is rather impossible due to numerical complexity. Moreover, even with FEA, the cases involving contact sliding are very complex and computationally intensive as they involve creation of grooves of displaced material and possible detachment of material similar to chip formation in a turning process. The recent literature134–140 is focused on modelling pile-up and sink-in in the classical indentation hardness tests mostly for rigid spherical indenters and only in terms of some basic dimensions such as the contact size and penetration depth. Shoulder height in pile-up is not calculated and shoulder geometry is not described analytically. Therefore, in regards to the present model, literature studies on pile-up effects offer very little in terms of useful analytical equations. In fact, only one type of equations can be used here to gain some insight on potential pile-up and sink-in effects, namely, an equation predicting the ratio s1/s0 (Figure 4). In this respect, there are several published studies predicting ratio s1/s0 and a good comparison of those can be found in the study of Bartier et al.135 The comparisons show that three of those models are particularly useful and have shown good agreement with experimental results, namely the models of Matthews140 (equation (39)), Hill et al.136 (equation (40)), and Hernot et al.137 (equation (41)) (39) (40) (41) where n, Y and E stand for strain-hardening exponent, yield stress and elastic modulus of the material of the indented solid, respectively. It is seen in equations (39) and (40) that the models of Matthews and Hill et al. depend on the strain-hardening exponent only, whereas the Hernot et al. model (equation (41)) accounts, additionally, for the Y/E ratio. According to Bartier et al.135 and based on experimental results, the models of Matthews and Hill et al. (equations (39) and (40)) lead to acceptable results for small penetration depths and for Y/E < 1/333. The Hernot et al. model (equation (41)) appears to be superior because it leads to acceptable results for greater penetration depths and broader range of Y/E (1/4200 < Y/E < 1/33). A comparison of the models of Matthews and Hill et al. with the experimental results of Norbury and Samuel141 by Taljat and Pharr134 shows that the model of Matthews gives slightly better results. However, it should be noted that all three models are valid for materials following the Hollomon hardening law (σ=Y1-nEnɛn, σ and ε standing for normal stress and normal strain, respectively); tensile tests of steels135 show that the Hollomon equation fits the tensile test curves only for plastic strain lower than about 0.3–0.4. Another constraint perplexing the analysis in case of pile-up is the restriction on dent shoulder height imposed by the available gap height or film thickness in dry or lubricated contacts, respectively. The shoulder height constraint used in the present model is (42) for the models of Matthews and Hill et al. (equations (39) and (40)) referring to the state of maximum load during indentation. For models predicting pile-up during unloading, constraint (42) cannot be strictly enforced unless it is assumed that shoulder height in the unloaded state is not significantly different than in the state of maximum load.

The aforementioned models (equations (39) to (41)) are used in the author’s numerical analysis—if the contact is purely rolling and if the models’ constraints are satisfied—for two purposes: (a) to check if piling-up or sinking-in is predicted based on the s1/s0 ratio being greater or lower than unity, respectively; (b) to obtain a rough estimation of dent shoulder height in case of pile-up by solving equations (39) to (41) for s1 using s0 ≡ wk(xp, yp) obtained from equations (35) and (36), R0 ≡ rk obtained from equation (24), E ≡ Ek and Y ≡ Yk (k = 1, 2), where s0 ≡ wk and R0 ≡ rk are computed at east time step during the indentation process.

It is obvious from the preceding introduction to the indentation models that due to their limited applicability, they are not of great value in the author’s debris model. Nevertheless, this introduction was necessary to show that piling-up effects are too complicated to be included in a numerical model of particle indentation in the general context of rolling–sliding contacts and without constraints in material plasticity properties. Furthermore, such effects have not been theoretically discussed in any of the published studies on debris particles to date.

sec.title: Experimental validation
sec.p: The numerical model was transferred to computer code compiled in FORTRAN 95. In fact, this was a major upgrade of a previously developed algorithm by the author, which has been used in several publications.59,62,97–99 Despite very extensive optimisations that were developed over a period of 12 months, the lengthy computer code requires processing times in the order of 5–30 h on a Pentium-4 equipped personal computer running at 1.5 GHz; this excludes the thermoelastic and subsurface elastic stress analysis explained in the study of Nikas.99 The validation programme for the code required hundreds of such computer runs lasting more than 1 year.

The model takes many parameters into account. For isothermal conditions, those include material properties (elastic modulus, Poisson’s ratio, mass density, yield stress, strain-hardening exponent, strain-gradient coefficient, kinetic friction coefficient), lubricant properties (density–pressure and viscosity–pressure functions, pressure–viscosity coefficient, specific heat capacity and thermal conductivity), ambient and operating temperatures, surface radii of curvature and velocities, contact load, initial particle diameter and percentage of particle’s work hardening. Thus, collecting complete and reliable experimental results to compare with the numerical predictions of the model proved very challenging. There are very few published studies containing experimental results adequately documented to offer the basis for proper comparisons. Those are the studies of Dwyer-Joyce,80,88 Dwyer-Joyce et al.,41 Ville and Nelias,68,81 Hamer and Hutchinson83 and Underwood.82 Even so, some ambiguous data such as the hardness of copper particles had to be decided based upon an extensive bibliographic research covering various sources. Such is the nature of the problem that attention to details is crucial.

Four cases of particles were analysed: (a) copper (soft) particles in rolling contact; (b) low-carbon steel (medium-hardness) particles in rolling contact; (c) M50 high-carbon steel (hard) particles in rolling contact; (d) M50 high-carbon steel (hard) particles in rolling–sliding contact. All numerical tests were done for a number of blocks Ny = 40 based on a convergence study and in view of saving computational time (each test still takes 7–10 h of processing time). A particle’s trajectory from the moment it is pinched to the moment its centre crosses the outbound of the Hertzian zone of the contact was divided to about 600–1000 time steps, depending on particle size and kinematic conditions. The input data used in the numerical model for each case are presented in Table 1 and also detailed in the following subsections. It is very important to present a detailed documentation on the derivation of said data values for the sake of scientific correctness and any future attempts to replicate these results meaningfully.

sec.title: Input data
sec.p: Simulation in this case is based on the experimental work of Dwyer-Joyce with the ‘Mangle rig’,80,85 which is an apparatus containing a pair of crowned steel rollers from an SKF roller bearing used to crush debris particles. Both rollers have 15 mm diameter, 20 mm length and crowning of 5.5 m radius (appendix A1.3 in the study of Dwyer-Joyce80). They rotate at 3000 r/min, resulting in peripheral velocity of 2.4 m/s, whilst supporting a hydraulically applied load of 2000 N (section 3.3.1.2 in the study of Dwyer-Joyce80).

The lubricant used is Shell Turbo T68 with 876 kg/m3 density at 15°C and kinematic viscosity of 68 cSt at 40°C and 8.8 cSt at 100°C (data from Shell datasheet LPDS/86/588). The lubricant remains at room temperature, which is estimated to be 24°C. Therefore, at operating temperature (24°C), the lubricant density is estimated to be 870 kg/m3 and the kinematic viscosity calculated from the previously listed values equal to 165 cSt, resulting in dynamic viscosity of 0.144 Pa s. Specific heat capacity and thermal conductivity of the lubricant are estimated equal to 1830 J/(kg K) and 0.14 W/(m K), respectively, based on typical data for mineral oils and synthetic hydrocarbon based oils (section 2.11 in the study of Stachowiak and Batchelor142). It is noted that the values of thermal properties are used to calculate a thermal correction factor for the film thickness separating the rollers according to section 20.8 in the study of Hamrock et al.;116 the range of variation of the thermal properties for typical oils is such that a small error in their estimation accounts for just a few nanometres difference in the film thickness, which is negligible in this case where the central film thickness is computed equal to 717 nm. Finally, the pressure–viscosity coefficient of the lubricant, which is used in calculating the central film thickness, is computed equal to 26.8 GPa−1 using the formula of Wooster (equation (2.11) in the study of Stachowiak and Batchelor142).

The SKF bearing rollers are made of through-hardened, carbon chromium steel, with macro-hardness in the range 7.0–8.5 GPa (714–867 HV) and average surface roughness 0.01 µm (Appendix A1.3 in the study of Dwyer-Joyce80). Typical values for the elastic modulus and Poisson’s ratio for this type of bearing steel are 210 GPa and 0.3, respectively. The strain-hardening exponent for this material (0.5) was calculated by the author from the engineering stress–strain data obtained by Dwyer-Joyce (Figure A2.1 in the study of Dwyer-Joyce80) via Brinell indentation (Tabor’s method143) after converting to true stress–strain and data fitting. The strain-gradient coefficient was not calculated due to lack of micro-indentation experimental data; it was thus set equal to zero. Finally, the broad range of the expected roller hardness caused significant delay in validating the model. Many tests were performed to cover the whole range of hardness. After an extensive literature search, including sources from steel manufacturer (SKF), it was decided to avoid extremes and use a realistic average value of 810 HV, the same as that used in Underwood82 for a similar test rig.

The particles used were spherical (Table 3.1 in the study of Dwyer-Joyce80). They were originally purchased in powder form and separated in size batches by a stack of wire mesh sieves. In this case, they have diameter in the range 58–63 µm (Appendix A1.1 and section 3.3.1.1 in the study of Dwyer-Joyce80). The numerical simulations were performed for an average particle diameter, namely D = 60 µm.

The material of the particles in this case is copper. Unfortunately, Dwyer-Joyce and co-workers41,80,83 do not provide precise hardness values for the specific copper particles they used other than a typical value range for copper, ranging from 40 to 100 HV (Tables 3.1, 3.6 and A1.1 in the study of Dwyer-Joyce80). This caused significant problems in the numerical evaluation. Depending on the manufacturing method, the hardness of commercial-purity copper varies significantly from 40 to 130 HV (Table 6.1 in the study of Hutchings92). Many researchers on debris-particle effects have falsely assumed that copper particles are of hardness lower than 60 HV. However, annealing and work hardening can result in micro-hardness values for copper in excess of 160 HV (see Figure 2 in the study of Poole et al.144) and, generally, much higher than values perceived in assuming that copper is not worked.145 Most importantly, there is a great difference between the macro-hardness of pure copper in bulk form and the micro-hardness of micrometre-size copper particles having undergone annealing and/or cold working. For example, micro-hardness of copper powder has been measured equal to 72 HV in the study of Eksi and Kulecki.146 Micro-hardness of high-purity (99.99% Cu) copper wires has been measured equal to between 90 and 110 HV—see Figure 3 in the study of Saraswati et al.145 The latter is more related to the present case because it accounts for work hardening in the production of copper. It was thus decided to use a value of 90 HV for the hardness of the copper particles, although many tests were done with different (higher and lower) values to check the trend of the results. Moreover, the work-hardening percentage was set equal to 60 following Dwyer-Joyce’s co-workers Hamer and Hutchinson;83 they measured this hardening on a Vickers micro-hardness testing machine using copper discs of 0.87 mm height, sliced from 1.58 mm diameter wire for their debris-indentation experiments. Finally, the elastic modulus of copper is taken equal to 130 GPa (Table A1.1 in the study of Dwyer-Joyce80) and density typically equal to 8940 kg/m3.

The kinetic (Coulomb) friction coefficient between a copper particle and a lubricated steel roller is difficult to be determined precisely. Measurements of copper sliding on stainless steel in 70% humidity at 40 cm/s resulted in friction with coefficient equal to 0.34 and decreasing trend for higher sliding velocities, as shown in Figure 6 in the study of Chowdhury et al.147 Considering that a typical value of traction coefficient in boundary-lubricated metallic contacts is about 0.1 and following an extensive literature search, it was decided to use an average representative value of 0.2 in the present case. Figure 5.
Numerical results for the indentation by copper particle (a) to (c) per section ‘Copper particles in rolling contact’ and low-carbon steel particle (d) to (f) per section ‘Low-carbon steel particles in rolling contact’. All cases are for a rolling contact. Figure 6.
Numerical results for the indentation by M50 steel particle per section ‘M50 high-carbon steel particles in rolling contact’ (rolling contact).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The dent predicted by the numerical model is shown in Figure 5(a) to (c). A circular, shallow dent with a narrow, central sub-dent or blind hole is visible. Side views of the dent in the rolling direction (Figure 5(b)) and transverse direction (Figure 5(c)) are shown. It was assumed that the elastohydrodynamic contact between the rollers in the absence of the particle is starved. This is believed to be representative of the conditions prevailing in Dwyer-Joyce’s rig80,85 because the oil is supplied to the contact by dripping through a funnel and the rollers rotate at relatively high speed. Thus, the central film thickness is taken equal to half that for full elastohydrodynamic lubrication (EHL), that is, hc = 358 nm. This has no effect on the trend of the results and the maximum dent depth will be affected by about 0.1 µm.

The numerical results in terms of dent and bottom-hole dimensions in comparison with the experimental results of Dwyer-Joyce80,88 are presented in Table 2 (case 3.1). The calculated maximum dent depth of 1.1 µm is very close to that found experimentally, namely 0.6–1.0 µm. In fact, excluding the narrow bottom hole shown in Figure 5(c), the depth of the main dent is 0.8 µm, which fits the experimental results right in the middle. (Moreover, it is likely that upon removal, the particle will leave part of its body inside the bottom hole. This would result in measuring a lower dent depth unless a metallographic analysis is performed to reveal the true material composition at the bottom of the dent.) The calculated dent width of 272 µm is also considered realistic given the experimental result of 200 µm (maximum) and accounting for the uncertainty in the determination of vital parameters of the problem such as roller and particle hardness, as well as the friction coefficients. The sub-dent or bottom hole is a common feature in dented rolling contacts and has been experimentally shown by Ville and Nelias,68,81 as is discussed later in section ‘The process of ductile-debris indentation’. It should also be noted that sinking-in is expected to occur according to the models of Matthews and Hill et al. (equations (39) and (40)). The Hernot et al. model (equation (41)) for pile-up/sink-in effects is not applicable in this case because its constraint n ≤ 0.4 is not satisfied. Table 2.
Validation of the numerical model by the experimental results of Dwyer-Joyce80,88 and Ville and Nelias.81
